text: You can use list comprehension for this:

code:
>>> map = [[-1, 2], [5, -3], [2, 3], [1, -1], [7, 1]]
>>> map = [m for m in map if m[0] > 0 and m[1] > 0]
>>> map
[[2, 3], [7, 1]]

text: If the list is not large, then the easiest way is to create a new list:

code:
In [7]: old_map = [[-1, 2], [5, -3], [2, 3], [1, -1], [7, 1]]

In [8]: new_map=[[x,y] for x,y in a_map if not (x<0 or y<0)]

In [9]: new_map
Out[9]: [[2, 3], [7, 1]]

text: You can follow this up with old_map = new_map if you want to discard the other pairs.
If the list is so large creating a new list of comparable size is a problem, then you can delete elements from a list in-place -- the trick is to delete them from the tail-end first:

code:
the_map = [[-1, 2], [5, -3], [2, 3], [1, -1], [7, 1]]
for i in range(len(the_map)-1,-1,-1):
    pair=the_map[i]
    for coord in pair:
        if coord < 0:
            del the_map[i]

print(the_map)

text: map is such a useful built-in Python function.
It is best not to name a variable map since this overrides the built-in.
If you do not have any other references to the map list, a list comprehension works best:

code: map = [[a,b] for (a,b) in map if a > 0 and b > 0]

text: If you do have other references and need to actually remove elements from the list referenced bymap, you have to iterate over a copy of map:

childList.text: actually remove elements from the list referenced bymap

code:
for coord in map[:]:
    if coord[0] < 0 or coord[1] < 0:
        map.remove(coord)

li = [[-1, 2], [5, -3], [2, 3], [1, -1], [7, 1]]
print li,'\n'


N = len(li)
for i,(a,b) in enumerate(li[::-1], start=1):
    if a<0 or b<0:
        del li[N-i]
print li

text: If you wish to do this in place, without creating a new list, simply use a for loop with index running from len(map)-1 down to 0.

code:
for index in range(len(map)-1,-1,-1):
    if hasNegativeCoord(map[index]):
        del(map[index])

text: You probably want del pair instead.
If the list is small enough, it's more efficient to make a copy containing just the elements you need, as detailed in the other answers.
However, if the list is too large, or for some other reason you need to remove the elements from the list object in place, I've found the following little helper function quite useful:

code:
def filter_in_place(func, target, invert=False):
    "remove all elements of target where func(elem) is false"
    pos = len(target)-1
    while pos >= 0:
        if (not func(target[pos])) ^ invert:
            del target[pos]
        pos -= 1

text: In your example, this could be applied as follows:

code:
>>> data = [[-1, 2], [5, -3], [2, 3], [1, -1], [7, 1]]
 >>> def is_good(elem):
         return elem[0] >= 0 and elem[1] >= 0
 >>> filter_in_place(is_good, data)
 >>> data
 [[2, 3], [7, 1]]

text: (This is just a list-oriented version of filter_in_place, one which supports all base Python datatypes is a bit more complex).
